ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My translation ability improved; I learned how to better contribute to group discussion, and do research on my own.
I learned to think of literary traditions and myths across genres, and, importantly, engaged deeply for the first time with Greek drama. More generally, my Greek improved.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Pauline LeVen is a remarkable teacher, and our syllabus was ambitious. Most students were engaged every day. As we began to read one text consistently, discussion slowed and lass became significantly less interesting.

The class's weakness was that there was not always a clear sense of the link between our translation work and the broader picture. It would also have been nice to read more literary theory alongside each author: that is, theory of lyric alongside Sappho, etc., to have a firm grip on each genre as we went. The great strength of the class was its students, and of course the instructor, as well as the undeniable interest of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not a first year Greek student.
Yes. This is a solid Greek literature class with interesting and diverse readings.
